justification: The article states that the drift rate parameter of the diffusion model represents processing speed, which is independent of decision caution and non-decision time. This measure is considered a process-pure estimate of processing speed.

According to the article, decision caution is represented by the boundary separation parameter in the diffusion model. This parameter indicates the amount of information sampled before making a decision.

The article explains that non-decision time, encompassing encoding and motor response times, is captured by the non-decision time constant parameters (τc and τn) in the diffusion model. Separate constants are estimated for correct and incorrect responses.

The article frequently refers to mean response times (RTs) as a traditional and basic measure of processing speed used in cognitive tasks, acknowledging its limitations compared to diffusion model parameters.
